title: Ticket #2640: SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS: reject condor_submit if fails
description:
Original idea from gthain.

New configuration setting: SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS. When a job is submitted, this expression is evaluated in the context of the job's ClassAd. If FALSE, the job is rejected.

Example use cases: 

# Jobs must explicitly set (Can't test =!=UNDEFINED since
# ImageSize defaults to executable's size
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS = ImageSize > 1000


#Forbid scheduler universe jobs
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS = JobUniverse != 7


# Require an AccountingGroup
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS = AccountingGroup =!= UNDEFINED

Possible extension: allow a list of tests so we can give more useful rejection messages: 

SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_LIST=SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN,SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_IMAGESIZE_MUST_BE_SET
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_IMAGESIZE_MUST_BE_SET_SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN = ImageSize > 1000
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN = JobUniverse != 7

then when a submit fails: 

% condor_submit myjob
Submitting job(s).
Job rejected because the following requirement(s) failed:
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN

remarks:
2014-Jul-24 19:52:42 by bbockelm:
In terms of keeping things consistent, shouldn't we have a SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_REJECT_REASON (similar to HOLD_REASON) instead?

2015-Jan-07 11:36:47 by gthain:
Does this fire on every remote commit? If so, if there are some jobs in the queue, then an admin sets SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS to false, do all shadow updates fail?

2015-Jan-07 12:35:44 by bbockelm:
Nope - this only fires for new classads in the transaction. The implementation of the pre-existing "ListNewAdsInTransaction" is: 

active_transaction->InTransactionListKeysWithOpType( CondorLogOp_NewClassAd, new_keys );

So, I think i works as advertised.

2015-Jan-08 15:31:13 by tlmiller:
As implemented: 

SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_NAMES = SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN, IMAGESIZE_MUST_BE_SET
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_IMAGESIZE_MUST_BE_SET = ImageSize > 1000
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN = JobUniverse != 7

produces 

$ condor_submit myjob
Submitting job(s).
ERROR: Failed to commit job submission into the queue.
ERROR: Submit requirement SCHEDULER_UNIVERSE_FORBIDDEN not met.

2015-Jan-08 21:44:11 by bbockelm:
Hi,

The auto-generated message is better than none - but significantly worse than what we would do locally with "SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS_REASON" that was there before. I really would not want to expose the auto-generated ones to users. Could you put it back?

Other than that, the other refactors look fine.

Brian

2015-Jan-09 14:39:23 by tlmiller:
I'm not sure what you don't like about the auto-generated ones; as long as the administrator chooses reasonable names for the requirements, they seem useful.

I strongly oppose the previous solution; writing nested conditionals to determine which clause failed and then returning the corresponding string is error-prone and mostly useless.

Instead, I'd rather implement SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_<NAME>_REASON, which would be a string to return instead of (or in addition to?) the default string. If you can come up with a good example, I'd be OK making it a ClassAd expression which evaluates to a string, although I might prefer SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_<NAME>_REASON_EXPR for that.

2015-Jan-09 14:40:51 by tlmiller:
Retroactive design doc draft --

https://docs.google.com/a/wisc.edu/document/d/1HywDThmWKoJVWIPOrgN58oaiiR0myYl8NPLaafIJ4Lk

2015-Jan-12 14:43:59 by tlmiller:
Implement SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_<NAME>_REASON as an expression, figuring people wouldn't mind adding quotes if they just wanted to use constant strings.

2015-Jan-12 15:04:57 by tlmiller:
(Documentation draft/notes -- Admin Manual)

Submit Requirements

You may wish to restrict which jobs may enter the queue of a particular scheduler. For instance, you may not wish to clog up your queue with jobs you know will never be able to run (for instance, standard universe jobs in a queue with restricted networking). Or you may require that all jobs in the queue request a minimum amount of memory.

To do so, set the configuration knob SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_NAMES. This comma- or space- separated list tells HTCondor the names of your submit requirements; pick something descriptive, since the name is a major component of the default error message if a user attempts to submit a job which fail to meet the requirements. For our example: 

SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_NAMES = NotStandardUniverse, MinimalRequestMemory

The names in this list must be valid configuration knob names. HTCondor sets each named requirement by looking up the configuration knob SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_<NAME>. Each knob must contain a valid ClassAd expression that evaluates to a bool (or something convertible thereto). For our example: 

SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_NotStandardUniverse = JobUniverse != 1
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_MinimimalRequestMemory = RequestMemory > 512

Note that JobUniverse and RequestMemory are both job ad attributes. Each submit requirement is evaluated (in the listed order) in the context of the the schedd ad (in the MY namespace) and the job ad (the TARGET namespace); attributes not found in the job ad will be look up in the schedd ad, as usual. The first requirement that fails terminates evaluation and is the only reason reported.

You may also set a rejection reason for each requirement: 

SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_NotStandardUniverse_REASON = "This schedd does not accept standard universe jobs; try again elsewhere."
SUBMIT_REQUIREMENT_MinimimalRequestMemory_REASON = strcat( "The job only requested ", RequestMemory, " megabytes.  If that's really how much memory your job needs, contact me at ..." )

A rejection reason has the same name as the corresponding requirement, except with _REASON appended, and must be a ClassAd expression which evaluates to a string. Thus, in our first example, we had to put double quotes around the whole explanation. In the second example, we construct a string using ClassAd's string manipulation funcations.

If you submit multiple jobs per cluster, please note that while we evaluate the submit requirements against individual jobs, any individual job failing the submit requirements will cause the entire submit to fail; the other jobs in the cluster will not enter the queue.

2015-Jan-12 15:09:21 by tlmiller:
Brian also suggested, as long as we're changing the protocol, that we should return a ClassAd instead of a bare string, for future-proofing. This is probably a good idea.

2015-Feb-12 14:22:04 by tlmiller:
Design doc updated; hopefully it became clearer.

2015-Feb-18 14:37:54 by tlmiller:
ToddT reviewed the design and found it generally acceptable. His concerns will be addressed in a child ticket.
